subject: Re: [junit] please do consider
msgSnippet: Hi george, Thanks for your mail. I m happy that i got a positive feedback. Meanwhile i have a new doubt about nUnit. While going thru old books i got a tool
messageBody:
Hi george,

Thanks for your mail. I m happy that i got a positive feedback. Meanwhile i have a new doubt about nUnit. While going thru old books i got a tool named X-Unity. Is this nUnit a revised version of that old X-Unity...?

GEORGE MCKINNEY <ghmck@...> wrote:
jUnit is one of a family of unit testing tools. While jUnit is in Java, others work in other languages. You can find a list of some of those at:
http://xprogramming.com/software.htm

under the Unit Testing heading. nUnit may be what you want.

It is my experience that the better you know the language you are working with, the easier these tools will be to use.

Good luck,
George McKinney

----- Original Message -----
From: nitin pallan <focus_on_me21@...>
Date: Wednesday, February 8, 2006 3:54 am
Subject: [junit] please do consider

> Hi i m nitin pallan. I m working as a software tester for the last
> 7 months. Now i am in a stage, that my organisation is asking me
> to study how to work with junit for a project. I dont know the
> exact process. I have gone thru some codings shown the helping web
> sites. U can u just help me out in knowing the entire process of
> how a Junit testing can be done. And on what all kind of languages
> it can be done. Also just tell me whether junit supports .net
> applications. If its not supporting can u help me in knowing the
> tools which does support .net applications.
>
> Hope that i get a positive feedback soon
>
> Thanking You
>
>
> NITIN EARNEST PALLAN
>
>
>
